speaker: Chris Jones
transcript: Has anybody thought about the energetics of CO2 binding? So when you look at the most successful molecules or materials out there they have strong enthalpically driven binding because of course absorption is disfavored from an entropic perspective. But of course if you're going to swing it off you've got to you've got to repay that that enthalpy penalty. So are there strategies one could employ to design more physisorbing sites that would still absorb CO2 selectively? And the nice thing about some of the inorganic or hybrid materials like MOFs is you imagine that your toolbox is huge for the types of sites that you could potentially design. So could you design a very high density of more weakly binding sites and still grab enough CO2 at these ultra dilute conditions without having to repay that massive enthalpy penalty that all these strong chemisorbing materials pay?
self_expression: inquisitive, expert, posing a detailed question
